verses.text: Pursue love and eagerly desire spiritual gifts, especially that you may prophesy.
verses.comment: Paul exhorts the Corinthians to seek love first, highlighting prophecy above other gifts for the edification of the Church. The preference for prophecy in communal worship points to an ordered ministry.

verses.text: For anyone who speaks in a tongue does not speak to people but to God, for no one understands; he utters mysteries by the Spirit.
verses.comment: Speaking in tongues is primarily vertical—between the speaker and God—and not for public understanding unless interpreted. It emphasizes the mystical nature of prayer.

verses.text: But the one who prophesies speaks to people for their strengthening, encouragement, and comfort.
verses.comment: Prophecy builds up the community, emphasizing the role of teaching and exhortation in worship and communal life.

verses.text: The one who speaks in a tongue builds up himself, but the one who prophesies builds up the Church.
verses.comment: Paul distinguishes between gifts for personal edification and those for the benefit of the whole, suggesting an ordered structure for spiritual gifts in the assembly.

verses.text: Now I wish you all spoke in tongues, but even more that you would prophesy. Greater is the one who prophesies than the one who speaks in tongues, unless he interprets, so that the Church may be built up.
verses.comment: Paul affirms tongues as a gift, but prioritizes prophecy for the good of the community. Interpretation is crucial for tongues to edify others, reflecting a liturgical principle.

verses.text: But now, brothers, if I come to you speaking in tongues, what good will I be to you unless I bring a revelation, or knowledge, or prophecy, or teaching?
verses.comment: Without interpretation or intelligible teaching, spiritual gifts lose their communal benefit. The stress on revelation and teaching hints at the need for authoritative guidance.

verses.text: Even lifeless things that produce sounds, such as a flute or a harp, if they do not play distinct notes, how will anyone recognize what is being played?
verses.comment: Music is intelligible only when notes are clear; analogously, speech in the Church must be understandable. This supports liturgical clarity and order.

verses.text: If the trumpet gives an uncertain sound, who will prepare for battle?
verses.comment: Clear signals are essential—whether in war or worship. Ambiguity in speech or doctrine leads to confusion among the faithful.

verses.text: So also with you: unless you speak intelligible words with your tongue, how will anyone know what is being said? You will just be speaking into the air.
verses.comment: Paul emphasizes intelligibility in worship, supporting communal participation and understanding.

verses.text: There are, it may be, so many kinds of languages in the world, and none of them is without meaning.
verses.comment: All languages are meant for communication; in worship, clarity is essential for unity among believers.

verses.text: If, then, I do not understand the meaning of someone’s language, I will be a foreigner to the speaker, and the speaker will be a foreigner to me.
verses.comment: Unity and mutual understanding are crucial for worship and fellowship; unintelligible speech divides rather than unites.

verses.text: So with you, since you are eager for manifestations of the Spirit, seek to excel in building up the Church.
verses.comment: Paul again prioritizes gifts that strengthen the Church. This verse subtly alludes to the structured and edifying nature of communal worship practiced from the earliest centuries.

verses.text: Therefore, one who speaks in a tongue should pray that he may interpret.
verses.comment: Interpretation is necessary for the benefit of all, emphasizing ordered ministry and the communal aspect of spiritual gifts.

verses.text: For if I pray in a tongue, my spirit prays but my mind is unfruitful.
verses.comment: Paul points out the distinction between spiritual ecstasy and rational understanding, reinforcing the value of intelligible prayer in the assembly.

verses.text: So what shall I do? I will pray with the spirit, but I will also pray with my mind. I will sing with the spirit, but I will also sing with my mind.
verses.comment: Paul models balanced worship, both spiritual and rational, laying foundations for ordered liturgy and prayer—spiritual realities expressed in understandable forms.

verses.text: Otherwise, if you give thanks with the spirit, how will someone occupying the place of the uninformed say 'Amen' to your thanksgiving, since he does not know what you are saying?
verses.comment: The communal 'Amen' indicates liturgical agreement and unity, which requires understanding—institutional liturgical participation is implied.

verses.text: For you may be giving thanks well enough, but the other person is not built up.
verses.comment: Personal devotion is good, but it must not come at the expense of communal edification. The 'building up' of others is a core principle of Church practice.

verses.text: I thank God that I speak in tongues more than all of you.
verses.comment: Paul does not discourage tongues but sets them in proper context and hierarchy among other gifts.

verses.text: But in church I would rather speak five words with my mind, so that I may instruct others, than ten thousand words in a tongue.
verses.comment: Teaching and understanding take precedence in the assembly, indicating ordered proclamation and catechesis.

verses.text: Brothers, do not be children in your thinking. Rather, be innocent as to evil, but mature in your thinking.
verses.comment: Paul urges discernment and maturity, both spiritual and intellectual, essential for growth in the faith and understanding of doctrine.

verses.text: In the Law it is written: 'By people of strange languages and by the lips of foreigners I will speak to this people, but even then they will not listen to me,' says the Lord.
verses.comment: Paul cites Isaiah, highlighting how unintelligible speech was a judgment against unbelief. Faith requires receptive and understanding hearts.

verses.text: So then, tongues are for a sign, not for believers but for unbelievers; prophecy, on the other hand, is not for unbelievers but for believers.
verses.comment: Tongues can serve as a sign to outsiders (as at Pentecost), while prophecy builds up those who already believe—demonstrating the Church's dual mission.

verses.text: If, therefore, the whole church comes together and everyone speaks in tongues, and outsiders or unbelievers enter, will they not say that you are out of your mind?
verses.comment: Paul cautions against chaos and confusion in public worship, encouraging order and comprehensibility for unity and witness.

verses.text: But if all prophesy, and an unbeliever or outsider enters, he is convicted by all, he is called to account by all,
verses.comment: Prophecy reveals the hidden things of the heart, leading outsiders to truth and conversion—an early form of evangelization.

verses.text: and the secrets of his heart are disclosed; and so, falling on his face, he will worship God, declaring that God is truly among you.
verses.comment: The effect of authentic, ordered worship and prophecy is to lead outsiders to worship and recognition of God’s real presence among believers.

verses.text: What should be done then, brothers? When you come together, each one has a hymn, a teaching, a revelation, a tongue, or an interpretation. Let all things be done for building up.
verses.comment: Paul describes a liturgical gathering, with varied roles and gifts, all intended for communal edification—a template for ordered worship.

verses.text: If anyone speaks in a tongue, let it be two—or at the most three—and each in turn, and let someone interpret.
verses.comment: Paul advises order and discernment in the exercise of gifts, with interpretation emphasized. This forms the basis for structured worship practices.

verses.text: But if there is no one to interpret, let each of them keep silent in church and speak to himself and to God.
verses.comment: Uninterpreted speech should not disturb the assembly. Silence before God is also a commendable posture in worship.

verses.text: Let two or three prophets speak, and let the others weigh what is said.
verses.comment: Discernment and judgment by the community is essential; this checks against error and supports apostolic authority.

verses.text: If a revelation is made to another sitting there, let the first keep silent.
verses.comment: Order and deference in prophecy maintain harmony and respect, reflecting hierarchical and communal leadership models.

verses.text: For you can all prophesy one by one, so that all may learn and all may be encouraged.
verses.comment: Paul encourages orderly participation, prioritizing instruction and encouragement—a vision of the assembly gathered for teaching.

verses.text: And the spirits of prophets are subject to the prophets.
verses.comment: Self-control is key, even in spiritual gifts; the faithful govern their gifts in obedience to communal discernment and order.

verses.text: For God is not a God of confusion but of peace—as in all the churches of the saints.
verses.comment: Peace and order are hallmarks of authentic assembly. The use of 'all the churches of the saints' points to universal practices, subtly referencing a wider tradition.

verses.text: Let your women be silent in the churches, for they are not permitted to speak but are to be submissive, just as the Law also says.
verses.comment: Paul references the Law and apostolic tradition regarding roles in worship. The principle here is one of reverence and proper order, which developed into structured liturgical practice.

verses.text: If they want to learn anything, let them ask their own husbands at home, for it is shameful for a woman to speak in church.
verses.comment: The teaching underscores propriety and order in public worship. This was reflective of early church gatherings, before development of later formalized ministries.

verses.text: Or was it from you that the word of God came? Or are you the only ones it has reached?
verses.comment: Paul reminds the Corinthians that they are not the source of revelation; the faith is received through apostolic transmission. This hints at the importance of established tradition.

verses.text: If anyone thinks he is a prophet or spiritual, let him acknowledge that the things I am writing to you are the Lord’s command.
verses.comment: Paul asserts apostolic authority. Submission to apostolic commands is a sign of genuine spirituality—a principle affirmed throughout church history.

verses.text: If anyone does not recognize this, he is not recognized.
verses.comment: Disregard of apostolic teaching leads to exclusion. This basis for church discipline echoes through later practice of maintaining orthodoxy under apostolic succession.

verses.text: So, my brothers, be eager to prophesy, and do not forbid speaking in tongues;
verses.comment: Paul affirms both gifts but with priority given to prophecy for the community’s good, reiterating balance and unity in worship.

verses.text: But let all things be done decently and in order.
verses.comment: Paul’s final instruction summarizes the chapter, affirming order and discipline as essential elements in communal worship, which became a hallmark of apostolic heritage.
